Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned authenticity of birth certificate and found inconsistencies in testimony

Credibility_Assessment: Inconsistencies Noted

Gender Guidelines

Legal_Issue: Procedural fairness in refugee claim adjudication, credibility assessment
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Administrative Law principles
Credibility_Assessment: Adverse credibility findings due to contradictions in evidence
Legal_Provision: Section 101 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, RPD Rules on late evidence
Basis_of_Claim: Fear of persecution based on claimed experiences
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Credibility of the claimant, timeliness and relevance of evidence
Application_Error: Failure to submit supporting documentation within required timeframe
Evidence_Ignored: Requested additional documents not submitted due to denial of extension
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness, standard of reasonableness on review
Application_Factor: Opportunity to present evidence, representation by counsel
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim dismissed, judicial review denied

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Misuse under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Legal_Provision_Violated: Marriage entered into primarily for immigration purposes
Application_Facts: Grabowski, an Indian citizen and German resident, married a Canadian permanent resident after brief employment in Canada; discrepancies in work history and marriage timeline were noted
Misrepresentation_Element: Discrepancies in work history and marriage timeline affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: Alleged lack of interpreter during interview
Evidence_Used: Inconsistencies in employment and relationship timeline
applicant's ability to understand interview without interpreter
Credibility_Assessment: Officer questioned credibility due to inconsistencies
Decision_Rationale: No breach of procedural fairness; decision supported by evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Marriage Fraud under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Dispute_Type: Immigration visa refusal based on suspected marriage fraud
Legal_Issue: Whether the officer’s decision was fair and reasonable in finding marriage not genuine
Credibility_Assessment: Doubt cast on motives for coming to Canada and consistency of relationship timeline
Evidence_Type: Cohabitation evidence presented but outweighed by inconsistencies
Legal_Provision: Marriage not genuine or entered for immigration purposes under IRPA
Basis_of_Claim: Suspected marriage fraud for immigration benefits
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Inconsistencies in meeting timeline and purpose of entry
Application_Factor: Brief employment in Canada prior to marriage

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Legal_Provision_Violated: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Facts: Applicant faced persecution due to domestic violence and threats from her ex-husband, a police officer, in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Overlooked key evidence regarding ineffective implementation of laws in Guanajuato
Evidence_Used: Evidence of domestic violence, threats from ex-husband, legal protections in Mexico, lack of effective state protection in Guanajuato
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of evidence on lack of state protection
Credibility_Assessment: Board's credibility reasoning impacted by failure to consider key evidence
Remedy_Sought: Remand for reconsideration by a new Board panel
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution or danger in home country with inability to rely on state protection
Decision_Rationale: Board's decision was unreasonable due to inadequate assessment of state protection and overlooked evidence

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false information in personal information form
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration inadmissibility decision
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer erred in concluding LTTE membership based on past activities
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.34(1)(f)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's admission of past LTTE-related activities and inconsistencies in PIF raised concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal Information Form (PIF), CSIS and CTS reports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Alleged membership in a terrorist organization based on historical involvement
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Minor, low-level activities conducted as a teenager under peaceful conditions
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to apply jurisprudence criteria for determining terrorist organization membership
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Lack of evidence of significant commitment or continued support for LTTE
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Membership requires evidence of commitment, involvement, and institutional link
Crimes.Application_Factor: Activities included selling soap and distributing pamphlets
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review challenging procedural fairness in inadmissibility determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the officer breached procedural fairness by failing to disclose key documents
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.34(1)(f)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Officer relied on undisclosed CSIS and CTS reports
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Decision set aside; case remitted for reconsideration by different officer
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to respond to allegations, but with right to know evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant’s explanations not properly considered due to non-disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of key decision-influencing documents
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness and compliance with procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Non-disclosure of CSIS and CTS reports affecting decision
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Officer’s conclusion on membership found unreasonable
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles of natural justice and procedural fairness
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No indication that government challenged procedural breach
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Set aside decision and remit for reconsideration

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility due to membership in a terrorist organization

Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Reasonable belief based on balance of probabilities
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of inadmissibility on terrorism grounds
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility set aside; remitted for reconsideration

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review challenging refusal of permanent residence

Application_Facts: Ms. Mueller was physically present for only 312 days but maintained strong ties to Canada, including property, social connections, and returning patterns.
Residency_Compliance: Yes, based on strong connection to Canada despite insufficient physical presence
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Evidence_Used: Property ownership, social connections, travel patterns, return history to Canada
Credibility_Assessment: Maintained strong ties to Canada; credible intention to reside
Decision_Outcome: Citizenship Judge found residency requirement met
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residency' as physical presence, temporary absence with strong ties, or centralizing mode of existence in Canada
Decision_Rationale: Ms. Mueller maintained strong ties to Canada, which supports meeting the residency requirement under a reasonable interpretation of section 5(1)(c)

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding that the applicants failed to give Colombian authorities a reasonable opportunity to investigate their claims of persecution

Key_Factor_in_Determination: Insufficient effort to pursue formal investigation with Ministry of Defence

Legal_Standard: State protection unavailable despite presumption in democratic countries
Application_Factor: Prior engagement with police and military

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on exposure to bribery and threats

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must prove persecution linked to a Convention ground

Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of threats, context of bribery, adequacy of state protection

Crimes.Defendant_Response: State protection is adequate and available
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and testimonial evidence regarding corruption and threats
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 96-98 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Sub_Crime_Type: Threats and coercion by corrupt union officials

Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Pattern of extortion by union actors

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Partially credible but not linked to Convention grounds
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Fear rooted in criminality, not protected grounds

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim based on exposure of corruption and resulting threats

Crimes.Institutional_Action: IRB assessed credibility and state protection

Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Presumption of state protection not rebutted

Application_Facts: Suspicion of association with a known criminal led to the suspension and subsequent revocation of the applicants' security clearances.
Procedural_Issue: Applicants were not given detailed reasons or access to the intelligence report before submitting their responses.
Key facts and opinions challenging their credibility were undisclosed.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of sufficient disclosure of information prevented meaningful participation.
Credibility_Assessment: The Minister relied on undisclosed opinions challenging the applicants' credibility.
Outcome: The matter is remitted for redetermination
Decision_Rationale: The duty of procedural fairness requires providing sufficient information to allow meaningful participation in decision-making, considering the nature of the decision, statutory scheme, and impact on rights. The Minister breached this duty by failing to disclose key information.

Legal_Issue: Failure to assess humanitarian and compassionate application on its merits
Governing_Law: Section 25 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Credibility_Assessment: Officer doubted family's presence in Canada
Legal_Provision: Section 25, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Officer's failure to consider merits of H&C application
Application_Error: Refusal based on outdated information and non-compliance allegations
Assessment_Standard: Mandatory consideration of H&C circumstances under Section 25
Evidence_Ignored: Substantive medical evidence regarding child's illness
Application_Factor: Child's health condition, family ties in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Order for reconsideration of H&C application

Legal_Issue: Whether a judicial review application is moot when removal is halted by a stay order
Basis_of_Claim: Deferral of removal sought due to child's medical issues
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of live controversy; substratum of judicial review disappeared
Legal_Standard: A case is moot if there is no live controversy or concrete dispute
Application_Factor: Adversarial relationship, judicial economy, precedential value

Application_Facts: Applicants overstayed visas and sought deferral of removal due to child's medical condition
Procedural_Issue: Mootness of judicial review after stay order issued
Legal_Standard_Applied: A case is moot if there is no live controversy or concrete dispute
Decision_Rationale: Removal date passed, stay order issued, no significant precedential value in deciding

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the applicant excluded due to serious criminality based on use of forged passport and false identity?
Crimes.Outcome: Federal Court set aside RPD decision
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's need to escape persecution was a mitigating factor not adequately considered
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Use of forged passport and fraudulent identity in the U.S.
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Serious criminality based on document fraud
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Maximum penalty vs. actual sentencing range and mitigating circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: RPD focused only on maximum penalties, ignored hybrid nature and mitigating factors
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Presumptively serious if max penalty ≥10 years, but must consider full context
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Possibility of summary conviction and applicant’s motive to flee persecution
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Supreme Court guidelines on seriousness assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Nature of offense, mode of prosecution, penalties, and individual circumstances
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Forged passport and false identity used

Crimes.Crime_Name: Providing false information in Personal Identification Form
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is providing false information in PIF a serious non-political crime?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Incomplete/incorrect info regarding U.S. convictions and identity use
Crimes.Evidence_Type: PIF inaccuracies, forged passport, fraudulent identity
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Serious criminality based on false statements and identity misuse
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Hybrid nature of identity theft (summary vs. indictable) and mitigating factors
Crimes.Decision_Maker: Refugee Protection Division (RPD), reviewed by Federal Court
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to consider full sentencing range and context
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Seriousness determined by max penalty (≥10 years) and contextual factors
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Potential for summary conviction (6 months) and flight from persecution
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Supreme Court precedent requiring holistic seriousness assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Elements of crime, prosecution mode, penalties, and surrounding circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision overturned, remitted for redetermination
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False identity and forged documents submitted

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was identity fraud a serious non-political crime under IRPA and Refugee Convention?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Use of forged passport and false identity to enter the U.S.
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On the party alleging exclusion under Art. 1F(b)
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Offense with max penalty ≥10 years is presumptively serious but requires contextual analysis
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of serious criminality based on identity fraud
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of identity fraud, max penalty (10 years), possible summary conviction

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Low risk of reoffending given context of flight from danger
Crimes.Threat_Source: Personal circumstances leading to illegal entry
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence of document forgery and identity theft
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Conviction records, travel documents, immigration forms
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Accepted as factual by RPD but context not fully assessed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Actions linked to escape from persecution, affecting moral culpability
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Hybrid offense allowing summary disposition with lower penalty

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Was the combination of shoplifting and identity fraud a serious non-political crime?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant used forged passport during shoplifting incidents in the U.S.

Crimes.Legal_Rule: Max penalty ≥10 years triggers presumption of seriousness, but full context required

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Conduct driven by necessity and survival
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Police records, court convictions, immigration documentation

Crimes.Application_Factor: False document submitted for immigration benefits
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Mr. Kobrosli found inadmissible; removal order upheld

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant meet the criteria for a stay of removal based on irreparable harm if returned to Sri Lanka?
Outcome: The motion for a stay of removal was dismissed
Credibility_Assessment: The applicant failed to prove irreparable harm on the balance of probabilities
Evidence_Type: Submissions, expert evidence from Mr. Schultz, PRRA Officer's findings
Basis_of_Claim: Risk of persecution in Sri Lanka due to high-profile Tamil gang leader status
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of specific threat or targeting of returnees like the applicant
Proceeding_Type: Federal Court review of stay of removal application
Legal_Standard: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Application_Factor: Non-speculative evidence required for irreparable harm

Risk_Assessment: No credible threat identified upon return to Sri Lanka
Risk_Type: Persecution claim based on identity and status
Evidence_Type: Expert testimony (Mr. Schultz), PRRA Officer report
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to provide contrary evidence

Risk_Assessment: No credible risk found upon return
Risk_Type: Persecution or harm due to profile
Targeted_Victimization: Claimed targeting not supported by evidence
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s claims not corroborated

Legal_Issue: Does the applicant qualify for a stay of removal based on irreparable harm?
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove irreparable harm
Legal_Rule: Irreparable harm must be non-speculative and likely
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution or torture in Sri Lanka
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Schultz and PRRA Officer reports

Legal_Issue: Qualification for stay of removal based on irreparable harm
Credibility_Factor: Lack of credible personal risk evidence
Legal_Rule: Must show serious issue and irreparable harm
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged personal risk in Sri Lanka
Key_Evidence_Considered: PRRA Officer and Mr. Schultz findings

Risk_Factor: High-profile status claimed but not verified
Evidence_Credibility: Official evidence trusted over applicant's claims
Key_Evidence_Issue: Lack of corroboration for personal risk
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s assertions not credible

Application_Facts: Convicted in Canada, challenged PRRA outcome
Credibility_Assessment: Claims not supported by evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious issue, irreparable harm, balance of convenience

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a narcotic for the purpose of trafficking
Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to serious criminality under immigration law
Application_Facts: Conviction led to removal order; challenged on risk grounds
Evidentiary_Deficiency: No objective evidence of irreparable harm
Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's claims unproven
Remedy_Sought: Delay removal based on alleged risk
Legal_Standard_Applied: Balance of probabilities for irreparable harm

Application_Facts: Ms. Ryan was absent for 1,136 days during the four-year period preceding her application, resulting in only 324 days of physical presence in Canada
Residency_Compliance: No – only 324 days of residence, falling short of the required 1,095 days
Procedural_Issue: Citizenship Judge applied a qualitative test instead of strictly assessing physical presence
Evidence_Used: Record of absences, evidence of ties to Canada, illness-related reasons for absence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient documentation or justification to offset prolonged absence under statutory requirements
Credibility_Assessment: Not explicitly challenged; focus was on legal interpretation rather than credibility
Remedy_Sought: Setting aside the decision and denying citizenship based on non-compliance
Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of 'residence' as physical presence with limited exceptions
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge's interpretation fell outside acceptable outcomes by allowing qualitative factors to override clear statutory residency requirements

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection exclusion based on alleged complicity in international crimes
Legal_Provision_Involved: Rule of 'personal and knowing participation' in complicity; 'reasonable grounds to believe' standard
Outcome: Applicant excluded from refugee protection due to reasonable grounds for belief in complicity
Grounds_for_Claim: Voluntary 16-year service in Sri Lankan army, participation in combat operations, mapping cordon and search missions, awareness of atrocities, failure to disengage despite opportunities
Legal_Framework: International law on crimes against humanity, principles of complicity, Canadian immigration and refugee law

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Dispute_Type: Refugee protection exclusion based on potential involvement in crimes against humanity
Legal_Provision_Involved: Standard of 'reasonable grounds to believe'; requirement of personal and knowing participation or toleration
Outcome: Board's determination upheld; judicial review dismissed
Grounds_for_Claim: Extended military service, direct operational role, knowledge of atrocities, renewal of service, trusted position within military
Legal_Framework: International criminal law, jurisprudence on complicity, Canadian Refugee Protection Division procedures

Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Applicant blacklisted by Chinese authorities after involvement in student uprisings, leading to difficulties in employment and education
Procedural_Issue: Federal Court found procedural inadequacy in Board's assessment
Evidence_Used: Evidence of blacklisting and its impact on livelihood, education, and employment
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board's conclusion lacked sufficient evidentiary support
Decision_Outcome: Board initially dismissed claim; Federal Court quashed decision
Outcome: Judicial review allowed, case referred back for redetermination
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of IRB decision and referral for reconsideration
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution involves serious restrictions on fundamental rights; discrimination must lead to substantially prejudicial consequences to constitute persecution
Decision_Rationale: Blacklisting affecting livelihood may amount to persecution under the Refugee Convention
Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in refusing the application due to the applicant's failure to attend the interview
Evidence_Assessment: Fax transmission records, consultancy firm's affidavit
Burden_of_Proof: Immigration officer must prove notice was sent; applicant failed to show non-receipt with valid reason
Credibility_Factor: Applicant's claim of non-receipt deemed speculative; consultancy firm's use of correct fax number supported delivery
Legal_Rule: Immigration officers must prove they sent an interview notice to the correct address or fax number. Rejection is permissible if the applicant misses the interview without valid reasons
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged procedural unfairness due to non-receipt of interview notice
Outcome_on_Merits: No error found in the Immigration Officer's decision
Key_Evidence_Considered: Transmission record of fax to correct number, affidavit from consultancy firm
Legal_Framework: Immigration regulations regarding notice and interview attendance
Defendant_Response: Notice was properly sent to the correct fax number used by the applicant’s representative
Authority: Immigration Officer, Court handling judicial review

Dispute_Type: Allegation of discriminatory remarks by immigration officers
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in law by dismissing a discrimination complaint due to lack of evidence and credibility issues
Governing_Law: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Evidence_Assessment: Conflicting evidence, lack of corroboration, prior investigations found no misconduct
Burden_of_Proof: On the complainant to establish credible evidence of discrimination
Credibility_Factor: Credibility issues with the complainant's allegations
Legal_Rule: Commission may dismiss a complaint if an inquiry is not warranted based on all circumstances
Outcome_on_Merits: No sufficient evidence to proceed; complaint dismissed on merits
Key_Evidence_Considered: Complainant's testimony, lack of supporting witnesses, prior investigation findings
Defendant_Response: Not explicitly stated, but prior investigations concluded no misconduct
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Commission's dismissal decision
Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed; Commission's decision upheld
Legal_Provision: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in refusal of Transportation Security Clearance (TSC)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant acknowledged incidents but failed to provide explanations; memory lapse not accepted as justification
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient information provided by Transport Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Applicant was given sufficient detail and multiple opportunities to respond
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires knowledge of allegations and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Application_Factor: Past associations and incidents reported by law enforcement
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or security documentation

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in refusal of TSC
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Incidents including illegal gambling were communicated; applicant did not deny or seek clarification
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of fairness
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant cited memory lapse but did not request further details
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires notice of allegations and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged lack of sufficient information provided
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Law enforcement reports on illegal gambling and associations
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Transportation Security Clearance process under federal regulation
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant failed to provide denial or additional information
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 18.1 of the Federal Courts Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of a controlled substance for the purpose of trafficking

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant stated she could not recall but did not dispute events

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in refusal of TSC
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant informed of adverse information including criminal associations

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant did not deny incidents or request further information

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Responded inability to recall, no denial submitted

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in TSC refusal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Detailed letter sent; applicant admitted lack of recall but took no action
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish unfair treatment
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Failure to engage meaningfully with process despite two opportunities
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires adequate notice and opportunity to respond
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected based on adequacy of communication

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Did not deny, clarify, or submit supporting references

Crimes.Application_Facts: Nabiloo was sentenced to over two years for drug possession; appeal of conviction was pending.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Subject to deportation due to inadmissibility
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Appeal to IAD dismissed due to lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: IAD lacked jurisdiction under s. 64(2) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed appeal; Federal Court dismissed judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious criminality based on imposed sentence
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: 'Punished' refers to the sentence imposed, not the outcome of a pending appeal

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 64(2) IRPA bars appeal during criminal appeal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Imposed sentence of over two years considered sufficient
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD appeal dismissed; judicial review denied
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On claimant to establish eligibility for appeal
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 64(2) IRPA applies if sentence is at least two years
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Challenge to IAD's lack of jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA provisions on inadmissibility and appeals
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued punishment not final due to pending appeal

Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacked jurisdiction; Federal Court dismissed application
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Convicted of drug offenses with three-year sentence
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Sentence of three years triggers s. 64(2) IRPA bar

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the RPD make contradictory findings and improperly assess evidence regarding the Applicant's identity?
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD questioned inconsistencies in testimony and rejected plausible explanations
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Credibility based on documentation and plausibility

Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found explanations implausible (e.g., document delivery method)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Contradictory findings and failure to address key evidence

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Did the RPD reasonably assess the applicant's identity and credibility based on the evidence provided?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: RPD questioned authenticity of documents and ignored business license
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 106 requires acceptable documentation or reasonable explanation
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unreasonable findings, ignored evidence, speculative conclusions
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Quash decision and refer to new RPD panel
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed, decision quashed, matter remanded

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the IAD correctly determined it lacked jurisdiction under IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA sections 64(2), 196, and former Immigration Act section 49(1)(b)
Crimes.Outcome: Application allowed; matter remitted to a different IAD panel
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections 64(2), 196 IRPA; former Immigration Act s. 49(1)(b)
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Automatic stay under former Immigration Act
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of automatic stay under former legislation
Crimes.Application_Error: IAD incorrectly applied section 196 by not recognizing automatic stay
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Interpretation of transitional provisions in IRPA
Crimes.Application_Factor: Sentence imposed vs. time served for appeal eligibility
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in dismissing appeal for lack of jurisdiction

Crimes.Violation_Type: Failure to comply with temporary resident status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: IRPA section 196 in relation to appeal rights
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant sentenced to four years for drug trafficking, appeal pending when IRPA came into force
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliance due to criminal conviction and deportation order

Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD had jurisdiction under section 196
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal sentence and status under former Act
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD erred in dismissing appeal; jurisdiction retained due to automatic stay
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review allowed; remitted to IAD
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Re-adjudication by a different IAD panel
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Interpretation of section 196 and transitional provisions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Automatic stay under former Act preserved appeal rights

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of drugs for the purpose of trafficking

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Application of IRPA section 196 to remove IAD jurisdiction
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction and sentence for drug possession with intent
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Adjudicator erred; IAD retains jurisdiction due to automatic stay

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued automatic stay preserved appeal rights

Legal_Issue: Whether 'Glen Breton' is deceptively misdescriptive under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: No Canadian whisky with 'Glen' in name before 2000; 'Glen' associated with Scottish whisky; consumer confusion evidence introduced on appeal
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate registrability; opponent showed likelihood of confusion
Credibility_Factor: New evidence of consumer confusion admitted on appeal
Legal_Rule: Marks that are deceptively misdescriptive or have recognized geographic association are not registrable
Grounds_for_Claim: 'Glen Breton' falsely suggests Scotch origin due to use of 'Glen'
Key_Evidence_Considered: Commercial usage of 'Glen' in whisky branding; absence of prior Canadian use; consumer perception data
Defendant_Response: Glenora Distillers defended trademark application as distinctive and not misleading
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, commercial usage records, consumer survey data (implied)
Remedy_Requested: Refusal of trademark registration by Scotch Whisky Association
Legal_Provision: Section 12(1)(e) of the Trade-marks Act

Application_Facts: Applicant was approved for citizenship but later convicted; Minister delayed notification and prohibited oath due to conviction
Procedural_Issue: Delay in notifying applicant of approval
Decision to close application without proper process
Outcome: Partially granted: past decision quashed, mandamus denied
Remedy_Sought: Compel Minister to allow swearing of citizenship oath
Legal_Standard_Applied: Mandamus criteria: public legal duty, clear right, no adequate remedy, practical effect
Decision_Rationale: Applicant currently ineligible due to criminal conviction; equitable remedy not available

Legal_Issue: Eligibility for citizenship after indictable offense conviction
Legal_Rule: Person convicted of indictable offense is statutorily ineligible for citizenship
Grounds_for_Claim: Approval should have been finalized before charges were laid
Outcome_on_Merits: No mandamus issued due to statutory ineligibility
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of citizenship approval, criminal charges, and conviction
Legal_Framework: Statutory ineligibility under Citizenship Act, availability of equitable remedies
Defendant_Response: Application put on hold due to criminal charges and conviction
Remedy_Requested: Writ of mandamus to compel citizenship oath
Outcome: Partially granted: past decision quashed, relief denied
Legal_Provision: Citizenship Act - ineligibility for indictable offenses

Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 220(a) of Criminal Code, Section 36(1)(a)(i) of IRPA

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Violation of procedural fairness in deportation decision
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Lack of reasons provided or opportunity to respond to H&C submission
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Applicant must show breach of procedural fairness and irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claim of lack of procedural fairness in decision-making
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Procedural fairness requires reasons and right to be heard
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness in handling of humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: No irreparable harm found despite procedural concerns
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Conviction records, absence of written reasons for refusal
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law principles applied to immigration decisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued lack of procedural fairness under Charter
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal to allow full hearing on H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 7 of Charter, Section 110 of IRPA

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable and consistent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Risk_Assessment: Personalized risk claimed, assessed as generalized by Board
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reasonable and consistent
Crimes.Legal_Provision: s. 97(1)(b) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

Crimes.Violation_Type: Abuse of power by state officials
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants victimized by police; claim of lack of state protection
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of Board's interpretation of personalized risk
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Board failed to adequately consider targeted nature of risk
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants found credible
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk was not generalized given repeated targeting by police

Legal_Issue: Whether the Director General breached the duty of fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to objections
Evidence_Assessment: Failure to provide opportunity to respond to objections prior to decision
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate breach of procedural fairness
Legal_Rule: Duty of fairness may require providing parties an opportunity to address objections in administrative processes
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness simpliciter or correctness, depending on context
Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of objections and lack of response opportunity
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, principles of natural justice
Defendant_Response: Director General proceeded with decision without addressing applicant's right to reply
Remedy_Requested: Quashing of decision via certiorari, costs
Outcome: Decision quashed, costs awarded to applicant, no referral back under s. 18
Legal_Provision: Section 18 (implied)
